articles.headline: One Thing America Might Buy With All the Spending? Less Inequality.
articles.snippet: The Biden administration is relying on Congress instead of just the Fed to fix the economy. That mix could lead to a less wealth-unequal future.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration is relying on Congress instead of just the Fed to fix the economy. That mix could lead to a less wealth-unequal future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has threatened to rapidly expand yawning gaps between the rich and the poor, throwing lower-earning service workers out of jobs, costing them income, and limiting their ability to build wealth. But by betting on big government spending to pull the economy back from the brink, United States policymakers could limit that fallout.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Money Market Funds Melted in Pandemic Panic. Now They’re Under Scrutiny.
articles.snippet: In March 2020, the Federal Reserve had to step in to save the mutual funds, which seem safe until there’s a crisis. Regulation may be coming.
articles.abstract: In March 2020, the Federal Reserve had to step in to save the mutual funds, which seem safe until there’s a crisis. Regulation may be coming.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve swooped in to save money market mutual funds for the second time in 12 years in March 2020, exposing regulatory shortfalls that persisted even after the 2008 financial crisis. Now, the savings vehicles could be headed for a more serious overhaul.

articles.headline: MacKenzie Scott Gave Away Billions. The Scam Artists Followed.
articles.snippet: She has no large foundation, headquarters or public website. That makes it easier to dispense money on her own terms — and for others to prey on the vulnerable in her name.
articles.abstract: She has no large foundation, headquarters or public website. That makes it easier to dispense money on her own terms — and for others to prey on the vulnerable in her name.
articles.lead_paragraph: Danielle Churchill needed help. She was raising five children in Wollongong, on the Australian coast south of Sydney, and had to cover thousands of dollars in special therapy fees for her 10-year-old son, Lachlan, who has autism. She tried crowdfunding on the site GoFundMe, but raised just a tiny fraction of what she had hoped for.

articles.headline: Republicans Target Voter Access in Texas Cities, but Not Rural Areas
articles.snippet: In Houston, election officials found creative ways to help a struggling and diverse work force vote in a pandemic. Record turnout resulted. Now the G.O.P. is targeting those very measures.
articles.abstract: In Houston, election officials found creative ways to help a struggling and diverse work force vote in a pandemic. Record turnout resulted. Now the G.O.P. is targeting those very measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Voting in the 2020 election presented Zoe Douglas with a difficult choice: As a therapist meeting with patients over Zoom late into the evening, she just wasn’t able to wrap up before polls closed during early voting.

articles.headline: As Covid-19 Devastates India, Deaths Go Undercounted
articles.snippet: Fatalities have been overlooked or downplayed, understating the human toll of the country’s outbreak, which accounts for nearly half of all new cases in a global surge.
articles.abstract: Fatalities have been overlooked or downplayed, understating the human toll of the country’s outbreak, which accounts for nearly half of all new cases in a global surge.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s coronavirus second wave is rapidly sliding into a devastating crisis, with hospitals unbearably full, oxygen supplies running low, desperate people dying in line waiting to see doctors — and mounting evidence that the actual death toll is far higher than officially reported.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Sameer Yasir, Hari Kumar, Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke

articles.headline: How the Trial Over Floyd’s Death Flipped the Script for Black Victims
articles.snippet: George Floyd was presented as a full person, not just a body beneath a police officer’s knee. Derek Chauvin, who was convicted in his murder, remained an aloof figure.
articles.abstract: George Floyd was presented as a full person, not just a body beneath a police officer’s knee. Derek Chauvin, who was convicted in his murder, remained an aloof figure.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — “His name,” the prosecutor said, “was George Perry Floyd Jr.”
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, John Eligon and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Biden’s Bet on a Climate Transition Carries Big Risks
articles.snippet: The president’s plans to cut emissions in half by 2030 relies heavily on a government effort to steer the development of new industries, but business leaders are fretting over the rapid timeline.
articles.abstract: The president’s plans to cut emissions in half by 2030 relies heavily on a government effort to steer the development of new industries, but business leaders are fretting over the rapid timeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s pledge to cut America’s climate warming emissions in half by 2030 is technologically feasible and, scientists say, ecologically imperative. Economically, it could be a gamble.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: C.E.O. Pay Remains Stratospheric, Even at Companies Battered by Pandemic
articles.snippet: While millions of people struggled to make ends meet, many of the companies hit hardest in 2020 showered their executives with riches.
articles.abstract: While millions of people struggled to make ends meet, many of the companies hit hardest in 2020 showered their executives with riches.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing had a historically bad 2020. Its 737 Max was grounded for most of the year after two deadly crashes, the pandemic decimated its business, and the company announced plans to lay off 30,000 workers and reported a $12 billion loss. Nonetheless, its chief executive, David Calhoun, was rewarded with some $21.1 million in compensation.

articles.headline: The Slander Industry
articles.snippet: Who makes money from destroying reputations online?
articles.abstract: Who makes money from destroying reputations online?
articles.lead_paragraph: Who makes money from destroying reputations online?
articles.byline: By Aaron Krolik and Kashmir Hill

articles.headline: We’re All Crypto People Now
articles.snippet: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies have gone from curiosity to punchline to viable investment, making them almost impossible to ignore — for better or worse.
articles.abstract: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies have gone from curiosity to punchline to viable investment, making them almost impossible to ignore — for better or worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Monday evening, a few days after a large cryptocurrency exchange listed its shares on the stock market, several hundred women gathered in a virtual conference room to talk about Bitcoin. Claire Wasserman, a co-founder of Ladies Get Paid, the company that co-hosted the event, marveled at the turnout, noting it showed “how committed you all are to getting wealthy.” She described a sweeping change in the way we live, work and transact — all driven by crypto. “I don’t want you to miss out on the future,” she said.

articles.headline: Millions Are Skipping Their Second Doses of Covid Vaccines
articles.snippet: Nearly 8 percent of those who got initial Pfizer or Moderna shots missed their second doses. State officials want to prevent the numbers from rising.
articles.abstract: Nearly 8 percent of those who got initial Pfizer or Moderna shots missed their second doses. State officials want to prevent the numbers from rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are not getting the second doses of their Covid-19 vaccines, and their ranks are growing.

articles.headline: ‘Chlorinated’ U.S. Chickens Convince British Consumers the Sky Is Falling
articles.snippet: Denounced by politicians and reviled by food safety activists, American-bred “chlorinated chickens” have become a symbol of all the U.K. fears about a looming trade deal.
articles.abstract: Denounced by politicians and reviled by food safety activists, American-bred “chlorinated chickens” have become a symbol of all the U.K. fears about a looming trade deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In this post-Brexit, mid-pandemic moment in the United Kingdom, with its economy battered by recession and the royal family in mourning and turmoil, it is hard to find a topic that unites this fractious nation. But U.S. chickens — yes, the lowly, clucking farm animal, consumed daily by the millions in all 50 states — have done it.

articles.headline: Half a Year After Trump’s Defeat, Arizona Republicans Are Recounting the Vote
articles.snippet: An audit of the vote in Arizona’s most populous county was meant to mollify angry Trump voters. But it is being criticized as a partisan exercise more than a fact-finding one.
articles.abstract: An audit of the vote in Arizona’s most populous county was meant to mollify angry Trump voters. But it is being criticized as a partisan exercise more than a fact-finding one.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — It seemed so simple back in December.

articles.headline: Michigan’s Covid Wards Are Filling Up With Younger Patients
articles.snippet: Even as vaccines roll out, more younger people in Michigan are being hospitalized than at any other point in the pandemic. And they’re coming in sicker.
articles.abstract: Even as vaccines roll out, more younger people in Michigan are being hospitalized than at any other point in the pandemic. And they’re coming in sicker.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROYAL OAK, Mich. — At Beaumont Hospital, Royal Oak, in one of America’s worst coronavirus hot spots, entire units are still filled with Covid-19 patients. People weak with the virus still struggle to sit up in bed. And the phone still rings with pleas to transfer patients on the verge of death to units with higher-tech equipment.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: As Outbreak Rages, India Orders Critical Social Media Posts to Be Taken Down
articles.snippet: Aimed at Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, the move sets up a clash over free speech amid a widening political and public health crisis.
articles.abstract: Aimed at Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, the move sets up a clash over free speech amid a widening political and public health crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — With a devastating second wave of Covid-19 sweeping across India and lifesaving supplemental oxygen in short supply, India’s government on Sunday said it ordered Facebook, Instagram and Twitter to take down dozens of social media posts critical of its handling of the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Karan Deep Singh and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Split-Second Decisions: How a Supreme Court Case Shaped Modern Policing
articles.snippet: Officers using deadly force rely on a legal doctrine set forth decades ago. Now, the movement launched by the death of George Floyd is trying to change that standard.
articles.abstract: Officers using deadly force rely on a legal doctrine set forth decades ago. Now, the movement launched by the death of George Floyd is trying to change that standard.
articles.lead_paragraph: In case after case, it took only a split second for an officer to pull the trigger.

articles.headline: Federal Aid to Renters Moves Slowly, Leaving Many at Risk
articles.snippet: Congress allocated $25 billion in December and another $21 billion in March to help people who fell behind on rent during the pandemic. Little has reached landlords or tenants.
articles.abstract: Congress allocated $25 billion in December and another $21 billion in March to help people who fell behind on rent during the pandemic. Little has reached landlords or tenants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four months after Congress approved tens of billions of dollars in emergency rental aid, only a small portion has reached landlords and tenants, and in many places it is impossible even to file an application.

articles.headline: Is an Activist’s Pricey House News? Facebook Alone Decides.
articles.snippet: The New York Post has complained that Facebook is blocking and downplaying its stories. But the platform doesn’t pay any special deference to journalists.
articles.abstract: The New York Post has complained that Facebook is blocking and downplaying its stories. But the platform doesn’t pay any special deference to journalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, I learned a new way to get a news article erased from much of the internet.

articles.headline: Terrorist Group Steps Into Venezuela as Lawlessness Grows
articles.snippet: With Venezuela in shambles, criminals and insurgents run large stretches of the nation’s territory. We traveled through one of the regions under their control.
articles.abstract: With Venezuela in shambles, criminals and insurgents run large stretches of the nation’s territory. We traveled through one of the regions under their control.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUARERO, Venezuela — They bring drinking water to residents in the arid scrublands, teach farming workshops and offer medical checkups. They mediate land disputes, fine cattle rustlers, settle divorces, investigate crimes and punish thieves.
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez

articles.headline: Breaking Point: How Mark Zuckerberg and Tim Cook Became Foes
articles.snippet: The chief executives of Facebook and Apple have opposing visions for the future of the internet. Their differences are set to escalate this week.
articles.abstract: The chief executives of Facebook and Apple have opposing visions for the future of the internet. Their differences are set to escalate this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At a confab for tech and media moguls in Sun Valley, Idaho, in July 2019, Timothy D. Cook of Apple and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook sat down to repair their fraying relationship.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: Why Some Black Democrats Haven’t Embraced a Voting Rights Push
articles.snippet: In the South, Black Democrats describe a party too slow in combating Republican voting limits. And Black lawmakers are wary that a major elections bill could reduce their power in Congress.
articles.abstract: In the South, Black Democrats describe a party too slow in combating Republican voting limits. And Black lawmakers are wary that a major elections bill could reduce their power in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — The right to vote is what Frank Figgers fought for in the 1960s as a student at a racially segregated high school in Jackson, Miss. It is what Medgar Evers died for when he was shot to death outside his home in the city in 1963, after his work with the state N.A.A.C.P.

articles.headline: To Be Tracked or Not? Apple Is Now Giving Us the Choice.
articles.snippet: With Apple’s latest mobile software update, we can decide whether apps monitor and share our activities with others. Here’s what to know.
articles.abstract: With Apple’s latest mobile software update, we can decide whether apps monitor and share our activities with others. Here’s what to know.
articles.lead_paragraph: If we had a choice, would any of us want to be tracked online for the sake of seeing more relevant digital ads?

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Carrying Guns in Public
articles.snippet: The justices, who have not issued a major Second Amendment ruling since 2010, will consider a challenge to a longstanding New York gun control law.
articles.abstract: The justices, who have not issued a major Second Amendment ruling since 2010, will consider a challenge to a longstanding New York gun control law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would review a longstanding New York law that imposes strict limits on carrying guns outside the home, setting the stage for its first major Second Amendment decision in more than a decade — and the first to be decided by the court’s newly expanded conservative majority.
